climbs.name: Carpe Diem
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Luc Gallant and Michel Martin Feb. 2017

content.description:
Easy rambly start off the beach can be easily soloed up to a good belay stance for pitch 2 where the real climbing starts. Pitch 2 starts off with a nice steep flow that eases off after about 25 meters and then necks down to a narrow gully to keep the climbing interesting. Pitch 2 and 3 can be combined but that can make finding an anchor difficult. Best to break it up.



This route is located about 300 meters east of Seige the Palace. Impossible to miss as the start is very unique. 

Stand rack of screws and draws.

climbs.name: Gnarlsberg
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Matthew Peck and Francois Guertin January, 2022

content.description:
Nice, steep, pumpy line that will get your motor running. It does protect well but finding good ice for screws could be challenging.



This is the first striking line you will see on the west side of Big Cove. 

A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

Needs a cold few days to form as there's a considerable amount of flow to the creek above. 



Access to the bottom: Follow the single track spur trail branching off the main trail at km 5.3, follow the odd flagging tape and follow it down to Little Split Rock cove (there's a few old ropes to assist going down the creek) 

Access to the top: Follow the single track spur trail branching off the main trail at km 5.3, follow the odd flagging tape and head towards the coordinates by following the cliff top trail around the Little Split Rock cove. 

Coord for the ice: 

45°19'43.0"N 64°29'29.5"W  

45.328610, -64.491536 

Screws and tree anchor

climbs.name: Pick or Pin
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Francois Guertin and Matthew Peck, January 2022

content.description:
Enjoyable route with lots of variety. The mixed section is not difficult but somewhat insecure with loose rock and engaging climbing through an offwidth/chimney section. There is definitely potential to take this route to the top with one or two more pitches of mostly rock.



Rap the White Line then walk 30 meters west.

Rack of ice screws and rock gear if you are not happy with running out the mixed section. There is a fixed pin in place but it may or may not protect the crux moves. To descend rap off v threads.

climbs.name: Seige the Palace
climbs.fa: Michel Martin, Luc Gallant and Greg Hughes Feb. 2018

content.description:
Really fun line that usually forms an impressive umbrella on the final pitch. 



This is that last long route on the north coast before the point. There are more routes to the west but in the 60 meter range. 

Standard rack of screws and draws.

At the time of this picture, the first half could be considered WI6 due to the fragility and lack of pro on the overhanging curtain and the last half would be WI4. If the stars align, perhaps the curtain could touch down and make it a WI5.

Tide: You have a 3hr window on both side of the low tide to access this area. 

Sun: Climb in the AM or when it's cold/overcast, the afternoon sun can start baking it in minutes.

Pro Tip: Climb in Hall's Hbr the day before and look accross the bay, if it's in, you should see a thin white line near the point of Cape Split!



Access to the bottom: Follow the single track spur trail branching off the main trail at km 5.3, follow the odd flagging tape and follow it down to Little Split Rock cove (there's a few old ropes to assist going down the creek) 

Access to the top: Follow the main trail until km 6, you should see a large map sign nearby, go straight accross the field until you hit the single unofficial track and head towards the coordinates. 

Coord for the ice: 

45°19'54.4"N 64°29'38.1"W  

 45.331776, -64.493924 

Screws and a few options for a relaxed belay station in the second half of the formation.

Very unique area and home to a provincial park. Cape Split is a long narrow piece of land that juts out in the Bay of Funday on the south side and the Minas Basin on the north. The north coast has the longest, steepest routes and with little to no sun they come in early and last late into the season. This area is close to the legendary Siren Song in Amethyst Cove. The rock is basalt but it is generally terrible. Stick to the ice. Walking the beach at low tide is the best way to find routes and check on conditions but there is a very convenient trail on top that leads all the way to the point.
